chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Never-out-of-tune Instrument Tuner simulates a full-featured instrument tuner. It may be used to tune musical instruments (guitars, pianos) with a cent precision.
NOOT Instrument Tuner is distributed under the GNU General Public License (see )
Should you find any unexpected behaviour or want to make a suggestion or request a feature, please go to the bug reporting page.
The author can be contacted on NOOT's mailing list:

sect1.title: Features

listitem.para: Easy to use (default settings will work in most cases)
It works with almost any instrument
Half-cent precision (0.005 semitones) or even better
Octave and/or note selection
Clock correction
Transposition
Clipping detection
Selectable temperament
Internationalisation (English and Italian for now, other languages will follow)
Cross-platform (it can be compiled on virtually any OS; Windows and Ubuntu packages available now, other packages available soon)
Basic documentation included
Two different frequency refinement algorithms

sect1.para: Future plans

listitem.para: Customisable temperament
More ports (OSX, ...) and languages
An audio card with a configured microphone or line input
Variable disk space (10 MB for the Windows version, 1 MB for Ubuntu packages, about 40 MB for universal packages)

chapter.title: Using NOOT Instrument Tuner
chapter.para: Before starting, you need to configure your input device. Commonly this means choosing an input device and adjusting its volume in the mixer.
After doing that, start NOOT. Usually there is no need for changing the default options.
Click on the Start/Stop button to start the tuner.
If you already know the note you are tuning and do not need to discover it, you should set the Note and Octave option (see and ). This will make note detection easier.

sect1.title: main window The main window
sect1.para: Here is an explanation of all the controls in the main window.

sect2.title: start/stopStart/Stop button
sect2.para: This button will start or stop the note detection. If another application need to open the input device, you can temporarily stop NOOT and restart it later, without closing its window.

sect2.title: note'Detected note' box
sect2.para: This box is made of two parts. The tuning indicator will show how much the detected note is far from the expected note. Its colour varies according to whether the pitch is higher (blue) lower (red) or quite right (green). If the note is perfectly tuned, the indicator should be under the black line.
The lower part of the box shows the following information:

listitem.para: noteThe detected note. This value depends on whether you have set the note and the octave in the control panel below. If they are note set to Auto, the note displayed will be exactly the choosen one.
offsetThe offset from the expected pitch, in cents (1 cent = 0.01 semitones)
frequencyThe detected frequency in Hertz. This information is useless to most of the users.

sect2.title: octave selectorOctave selector
sect2.para: Selecting the right octaves improves the precision of the detection and the readability of the indicator. When the octave is set to Auto, the program guesses it, sometimes leading to a note detection error.
With the standard used the middle C is in octave 3.

Sometimes the right octave is not the best choice, since in some cases (especially with extreme notes) the base frequency is too soft to be detected precisely. If the detection is not precise enough (i.e. the indicator glitches or vibrates too much) you can safely select an octave lower or higher than the original one. Remember that if you set the octave in the control panel, the detected octave may not correspond to that of the note. (For other advice see ).

sect2.title: note selectorNote selector
sect2.para: Like for the octave, specifying the note oftens improves the precision, but in most cases you should not need it.

sect2.title: listen'Listen' button
sect2.para: Click on this button to listen to the frequency of the note selected.

sect2.title: temperamentTemperament selector
sect2.para: With NOOT Instrument Tuner you can choose among a variety of temperaments. The explanation of the temperaments listed is not a subject of this manual.

sect2.title: transposeTranspose
sect2.para: Use this control to transpose the input. It can be a decimal number.
The frequency displayed above will not be altered, but the note and/or the offset in cents may be.

sect2.title: FFTwindow sizeWindow size
sect2.para: This option affects the note detection algorithm. It represents the number of samples on which the FFT and autocorrelation (or continuous powr spectrum) are performed.

The optimal window size depends on the refinement algorithm selected. Consider however that in any case a bigger window implies a more accurate measure, at the cost of reducing the reactivity of the program and increasing the CPU usage.

If the default algorithm is set (Continuous power spectrum), the window size can be set at any value (at least 1/5 of the sample rate). If the alternate algorithm (Autocovariance) is selected, then when the window size is too little, the precision constraint might not be satisfied, and therefore no result is shown. The optimal window size in the latter case is between 16384 and 32768.

sect2.title: noisethresholdThreshold
sect2.para: This option is used to start the detection only if the input is loud enough, in order to avoid glitches due to the background noise. The threshold is displayed graphically as a thin black line in the volume meter.
A threshold of 0 dB means that the detection will never start, while a threshold of 90 dB (-90 dB, actually) will allow any input to be processed.

sect2.title: expected precisionExpected precision
sect2.para: The lower is this number, the higher will be the precision. It represents the theoretical error in thousandths of semitone on the detected frequency.
Lower values also mean slower response and CPU usage.

sect2.title: frame rateFrame rate
sect2.para: This number represents the maximum number of updates per second. If it is set to a too high value, the program might not fulfill the request or even slow down.

sect2.title: Status barclipping detectionstatus barvolume meter
sect2.para: The status bar is composed of three boxes. The first contains information about the current status (Listening, Paused, etc.).
The second box contains two numbers: sampling frequency and clock correction factor (see ).

The third box contains a volume meter. The thin black line represents the current threshold. Note detection happens only when the input volume is higher than the threshold. The volume meter turns red when possible clipping is detected. In case, the user should lower the volume, as clipping alters the frequency detection.

sect2.title: Devices
sect2.para: This menu contains options to select the input and output devices.

sect2.title: Other options
sect2.para: Through this menu you can change the current sampling rate and clock correction. See for detailed instructions.

sect3.title: Change sample rate
sect3.para: This menu item opens a window listing some of the possible sample rate for the device selected. Sample rate should be as low as possible if the “Continuous power spectrum” refinement algorithm is selected, as high as possible otherwise.

sect3.title: Clock correction
sect3.para: The clock correction factor is a number that multiplies the detected frequency. Set this option if your sound card has an inaccurate clock. Clock correction can be set as a coefficient or in terms of cents (hundredths of a semitone). (See .)

sect3.title: Window type
sect3.para: This is a rather techical option. It should always be Hanning, unless you have some serious reason to change it.

sect3.title: Refinement algorithm
sect3.para: This options define the algorithm use to increase the precision of the frequency estimated in the first step.

listitem.para: Don't perform any refinement (useful only for testing, it gives very bad results)
The old algorithm (up to version 0.2.x)
The new algorithm, faster and more reliable with extreme notes.

sect3.para: The default is Continuous power spectrum.

sect3.title: Table of contents
sect3.para: This menu item opens the table of contents of this book.

sect3.title: Context help
sect3.para: Click on this menu to open the documentation at the page related to the currently selected control.

sect3.title: Project website
sect3.para: This menu opens the default browser on NOOT's website.

sect3.title: Report a bug
sect3.para: Click on this menu if you want to report an abnormal behaviour or to request a new feature. The default browser will open on NOOT's issue tracker. Fill in the form following the instructions given.

sect1.title: Clock correctionclock correction
sect1.para: Most cheap sound cards have inaccurate clocks, that lead to a bias in the frequencies detected and thus biased values in the Offset box (with biases up to a few cents). The clock correction factor is a number that multiplies the detected frequency, thus cancelling the bias.

You can easily calibrate NOOT for your sound card by using a tuning fork (or an equivalent instrument). The clock correction factor in cents is the opposite of the Offset value shown when the tuning fork is struck near the microphone.

sect1.title: The right sampling ratesample rate
sect1.para: With the default algorithm (Continuous power spectrum), the best sampling rate is the lowest, provided that it's at least two times the maximum frequency to be measured. Usually 8000 or 16000 Hz will go.

With the autocorrelation-based algorithm, the best sampling rate is the highest. However, if the note isn't detected correctly, or if you see glitches, you can consider lowering it, taking into account that lower sampling rates cause longer reaction times.

sect1.title: Tuning extremely high or low notes
sect1.para: Extreme notes are those below 100 Hz and above 3000 Hz. These are not easily detected by the program. In order to make the tuner work well with these notes, you should first set the Note and Octave options in the main window, to prevent NOOT from detecting a wrong note. Then, you should raise the Expected precision option. NOOT cannot always satisfy the precision constraint with extreme notes.

chapter.title: How it works
chapter.para: NOOT Instrument tuner implements a two-step method to estimate a frequency with one-cent precition with relatively narrow window sizes. In the first step, the program computes the FFT of the input signal, and finds an initial range in which the frequency to be measured should be. Then, a refinement algorithm improves the measure.
In the first versions of NOOT, an autocovariance-based refinement algorithm were used. Now the default method computes a close approximation of the continuous power spectrum of the audio signal.
With the old approach, every time the display is updated, the following algorithm is computed on the current window:

listitem.para: A FFT is used to find the frequency with the highest spectral density within the note and octave constraints (if selected)
From that frequency, an interval of possible frequencies is taken.
Autocorrelation is computed at the times corresponding to that frequency interval; the time lag corresponding to the highest autocorrelation is kept.
Repeatedly, the frequency is halved (the time lag is doubled) and the time lag corresponding to the highest autocorrelation among the near values is kept.

chapter.para: The main disadvantage of this approach is that it ceases to be precise in cases when the harmonics are far less than perfect.

With the new approach, the signal is compared with a wave having a frequency in the range detected in the first step through linear with a function similar to the linear correlation. Then the frequency of this wave is changed slightly at each step in order to find the waveform which is more similar to the signal, until the required precision is expected.

sect1.title: No note is detected
sect1.para: I.e. the Note, Frequency, and Offset fields do not show anything.

listitem.para: The volume may be too low or the threshold too high. Look at the volume meter in the lower-right corner and check that the gauge goes past the thin line when a note is produced. Check the input volume of your sound card.
You may have selected the wrong input device. If the volume meter does not move at all, select another input device in the Devices menu.

The expected precision could be too high for the window size selected. Select Auto as window size or raise the Expected precision value. Select Continuous power spectrum as refinement algorithm (from the Other options menu).
Facilitate the work of the program by telling what note or at least what octave you are tuning. (Set the Note and Octave options.)
You may need extra precision: try raising the Window size.

Try setting the Octave and Note options. If the indicator does not stabilize, try raising the Window size and/or lowering the Expected precision option and/or raising the sampling rate. If you are tuning an extremely high or low note (as in the piano) follow the instructions in .

sect1.title: The program crashes or freezes
sect1.para: This should not happen. Please file a bug.
